text:
500 ml bottle bought at Just Green in SoHo, Central.
Looks: Translucent pale pear juice colour; Near zero head with residual soapy white foam which fades in 5 seconds; No lacing with active carbonation.

Aroma: Fragrant and very sweet pear wine, with strong yoghurt tartness, strong alcohol, sandalwood, funk, nice pear flesh, strong floral, strong sugar and strong tannic.

Taste: Medium sweet pear wine, with very strong yoghurt tartness, alcohol, strong liquorices, pear flesh, funk, sugar, fair wood barrel and tannin.

Body: Light body. Quite slick palate. 

Mouth Feel: Strong and fleshy pear wine with very well balanced strong sweetness and strong yoghurt tartness, touched by nice funky wood barrel throughout. Quite boozy with strong liquorices and fair tannin for a chop-licking medium bitter finish. Very nice!

After Taste: Fairly dry. Sweet, boozy funky and bitter to mouth.

Comments: This one is strong in aroma and taste - fruity peary, sweet, tart, boozy and woody - with the funky character an unexpected bonus. More than a match for my favourite Marks & Spencer Pear Cider, this is sweet strong cider at its best. Recommended!

Small sample during Carnivale Brettanomyces 16. Pours clear yellow with no head. Aroma has some grapes, pear, citrus and tartness. Taste is relatively sweet with some fruitiness and pears. Medium body and carbo.

Bottle @ Carnivale Brettanomyces 16: Served in a taster:
White vinous look a like.. No head...
Nose of pear and light funk...
Flavour is funky pear with light wood...
No carbo, soft mouthfeel, medium bodied...
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle sample at In De Wildeman during Carnival Brettanomyces 2016. Amsterdam, The Netherlands. 24.06.2016. Taste with Ogi and Aart. Thanks Gene. Pour it hazy yellow color with no head. Aroma pear, some elderflower on the back. Taste sweet, floral, pears, bitter just a pinch, maybe not the right time to taste this one but its ok.
Bottle. Pale blonde. Peararoma with citrus and soft floral notes. Pear in the flavor with soft yeasty notes, tannines, citrus. Not too sweet.

Sample from bottle shared by @Travle at In de Wildeman during Carnivale Brettanomyces 2016 pale yellow/golden with no head, looks like a white wine. Aroma of fruits, pears, sweet, soft. Taste is very nice, sweet and sour pears, soft, nice sweet, average body, quite ok,

500 ml. bottle shared by Travlr @ In De Wildeman during Carnivale Brettanomyces 2016! Thank you sir! Very pale golden, few thin streams of bubbles rising & no head. Nose is mellow sweetish pear, low sweet pear, sweet but not heavily so. Taste is low mineral, touch sulfur-like note, basic sweet pear, not very expressive. Low fine carbonation, sweet but not extremely so. About okay.

Sampled from bottle at In de Wildeman during Carnivale Brettanomyces 2016. Clear, pale straw yellow. Sourish-fruity aroma of pear, some apples and a touch of gooseberry. Sweetish, slightly sourish, fruity taste of pear, apple and white grapes, followed by a short, slightly tart and dry finish. Thin to medium body, slightly effervescent and quite astringent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Nice!
Sampled from bottle. Thanks for sharing Gene. Clear very pale golden color, no head. Smell and taste pear, sweetness, slightly sugar. Average body and soft carbonation.
Bottle at In De Wildeman. Crystal clear pale yellow color, champagne bubbles. Decent fruit aroma. Taste is lightly tart, dry, fruity, quick finish.

500ml bottle. Pale yellow colour, short-lived white foam head and aroma of fruity pear. Taste is pear, woody oak with buttery & biscuity notes plus some hay & tannins. Slick mouthfeel, light bodied, medium carbonation, buttery biscuity & harsh straw note at the finish.

This is nice better than fake pear ciders and I like them ha. But I feel special drinking this bit weird but pears are. Much sweeter than cider. But not to bad, too thin and refreshing to be called medicinal, heady buzz nice not mind blowing but special enough

500ml bottle from Dunkertons Cider Farm, Herefordshire. Pours clear gold, with a sweet fruity perry aroma. Taste is distinctive Dunkertons; fruity, exceedingly well blended and underpinned by just the right amount of tannins.. I could drink this all day long.

50cl bottle. Pours golden and slightly hazy with very gentle bubbles. The nose has over-ripe pear. The taste confirms the over-ripeness but finishes with a dry tangy finish. Im not sure why the scores for this are so low - theres obviously depth of flavour and a good balance between initial sweetness and the dryness of the finish. I like this.

Bottle @ In De Wildeman. Clear champagne colour without head. Aroma is sweet, pear and a little tart. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. Very refreshing and no sign of the relatively high ABV. 260712
Golden with moderate fizz. Pear juice, oak and some medium dryness. Easy to drink but with not much character. Oh, for a drop of Gwatkins on draught.........
Smells boozy and sweet.  Tastes like a dog/cat that was shampooed about a week before. Really not into the flavour but the, Im really not into Perry.

Comments: A bit sweet and medicinal sparkling perry that does not satisfy as much as their ciders.

Bottle from Waitrose. Hey a bottled Perry. I was surprised. I admit that I am somewhat of a fan of this style of alcoholic refreshment.  Greeny gold colour with disappearing white head. Not intense pear aroma. Bit of rubber in mouth with nice solid pear flesh. Finish has some dryness, but mostly fruit. Very clean. Fruit gets better as it goes on. No real complexity, but nicely subtle.

Pale yellow & gold.  Aromas are sweet pear with some wood, has something of the farmyard about it.  Flavours are sweet and peary (is that an adjective?) with more of the Dunkertons "wood and the trees" oakiness at the finish.  I think this is the only perry I have seen bottled.  Pretty good.  My fondest memory of Perries is my fest-newby friend puking it up at Peterborough beer fest a few years back - after just a pint of the stuff.  Ah, perries.
Bottle (Waitrose). Cloudy lemon with no head yet gentle carbonation. Oaky pear aroma, slightly funky. Sweet pear taste with a funky medicinal finish. Ok.

Bottle, from Waitrose in Lincoln. Hazy yellow gold, no head and gentle but quickly disappearing condition. Gentle sweet fruity pear notes in the nose, sweet and fruity in the mouth with hints of candy and a sweet, oily finish with a touch of woodiness and retronasal (my new favourite word, thanks Joris) alcohol.
